trial_identification.studytitle: Exercise to improve heart and brain health following stroke
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Aerobic exercise to improve cardiovascular and neurological health outcomes in the chronic stroke population

interventions.interventions: Patients are randomised to participate in aerobic exercise three times a week for 12 weeks or usual care. The exercise classes include stations of treadmill training, stationary cycling, arm and/or leg ergometry and weight bearing exercise such as steps and overground walking and last for 1 hour. Blinded assessment of outcome is performed at baseline, 3 and 6 months.
interventions.comparator: Usual care provided by patients' general practitioner and allied health professionals, excluding supervised aerobic exercise programmes for 12 weeks, the same duration as the exercise group.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Cognitive function using the following 4 tests, and combined to form a Z score: Trail making test B, the Free and Cued Selective Reminding test, Inspection time, and modified Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline, 3 and 6 months following randomisation

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Physical abilities using the following tests: the Timed Up and Go, the 6 Minute Walk Test, gait velocity and the Sit-to-Stand test
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline, 3 and 6 months following randomisation

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Cognitive function using the following tests: The Stroop test, Verbal fluency, Trail making tests A and B, The Grober and Buschke Free and Cued Selective Reminding test, digit span backwards and forwards, spatial span test, Inspection time and Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline, 3 and 6 months following randomisation

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Cerebral blood flow and vessel reactivity using transcranial doppler ultrasound
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline, 3 and 6 months following randomisation

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of life assessment using the Assessment of Quality of Life tool (AQoL)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline, 3 and 6 months following randomisation

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Cost effectiveness and cost utility using the AQoL to calculate quality adjusted life years (QALYs)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline, 3 and 6 months following randomisation

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Response to stimulation of the motor cortex to induce plasticity using repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline, 3 and 6 months following randomisation

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Peak oxygen uptake (VO2 peak) using a submaximal exercise test (the Physical Work Capacity test at 75% of age-predicted maximum heart rate) on a recumbent cycle and open-circuit spirometry
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline, post intervention (3/12) and then 6 months post intervention (9/12 after baseline)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Diagnosis of first or recurrent stroke, haemorrhage or infarct at least 6 months prior to entry into the study.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Patients who are unable to participate in an exercise programme due to medical conditions such as heart failure, unstable angina, dementia and receptive aphasia. Patients on beta-blockers. Patients already participating in a supervised aerobic exercise programme. Patients who have epilepsy, metallic implants in the skull or cardiac pacemakers will be excluded from the transcranial magnetic stimulation.

trial_design.concealment: Allocation was performed by a person independent to the study and concealed in sealed opaque envelopes. After baseline testing, the research assistant not blinded to group allocation contacted this researcher and informed the participant of group allocation. The outcome assessor remained blinded to allocation until after the statistical analyses were completed
trial_design.sequence: The random sequence was generated using software by researchers not involved with participants or data collection. There was no stratification. This was decided before the first participant was recruited

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Aerobic exercise can improve cardiovascular fitness, mobility and physical function following stroke but it is not known whether it has an effect on cognitive and neurological function. We intend to compare a 12 week exercise program with usual care to document changes in impairment, activity and participation, as well as performing a cost-effectiveness study.
